headline.main: National Briefing | Science And Health: Pioneer Astronaut Departing

results.snippet: Eileen M. Collins, the first woman to pilot and command a space shuttle, said she would leave NASA. Ms. Collins, 49, said she wanted to spend more time with her family and to pursue other interests. Last July she added to her string of firsts by...
results.lead_paragraph: Eileen M. Collins, the first woman to pilot and command a space shuttle, said she would leave NASA. Ms. Collins, 49, said she wanted to spend more time with her family and to pursue other interests. Last July she added to her string of firsts by leading the flight in space after the Columbia disaster in 2003. In a statement, Ms. Collins said she hoped to continue working in the aerospace industry but she did not offer details.

results.abstract: Mark Gill resigns as head of Warner Brothers' independent film division; is expected to be succeeded by production executive Polly Cohen; Gill and Warner president of production Jeff Robinov often clashed on issues of management style; photo (M)

headline.main: Head of a Warner Brothers Film Unit Steps Down

results.snippet: The move was something of a surprise in Hollywood, since the specialty unit, after a slow start in 2003, enjoyed success last year.
results.lead_paragraph: After nearly three years of struggling to reconcile the leadership of its specialty unit with the parent studio, Warner Brothers has thrown in the towel and ushered out Mark Gill, the veteran independent film executive who started the Warner Independent Pictures division. Late Tuesday, Mr. Gill submitted his resignation from New York, where he was attending the Tribeca Film Festival with Chen Kaige, the Chinese director of the Warner Independent movie ''The Promise.'' Mr. Gill will become a producer on the Warner lot.

headline.main: Breaking Into the Biz? Or Broken?

results.snippet: At Portfolio Night, young people, hoping to penetrate the competitive ad industry, get their work examined by ad executives.
results.lead_paragraph: THERE are not a lot of job openings on the highly coveted creative side of advertising agencies, but there are lots of hopefuls desperate to land one. So desperate that nearly 75 aspiring young creative types paid $35 each, and in many cases traveled across the country, to attend Portfolio Night, an industry-sponsored event last Thursday that put attendees face-to-face with their professional idols: creative directors and copywriters.

results.abstract: American Ballet Theater has joined forces with Long Island University to give its dancers opportunity to take college courses taught by university faculty members; venture, called LIU at ABT, places Ballet Theater among small group of American companies that help their dancers get college educations; dancers pay only third of their tuition with university offering one-third tuition scholarship and Lewis Ranieri, chairman of ABT's board, providing funds for rest; with credits offered for life experience, dancer could earn bachelor's degree in five or six years; photo (M)

headline.main: College Classes for Dancers Reveal World Beyond Ballet

results.snippet: Last fall American Ballet Theater joined forces with Long Island University to give its dancers an opportunity to take college courses taught by university faculty members.
results.lead_paragraph: All the usual accouterments of a ballet studio were there: the worn gray floor, the metal ballet barres, the vague smell of human effort that still hung in the air. But the class at American Ballet Theater's studios last week was not in dance. It was part of a college physics course that was drawing to an end. The students, all members of Ballet Theater, seemed a typical jumble of sneakers and jeans, except for Elizabeth Mertz, a member of the corps de ballet, who had stretched herself into a languorous side split on the floor as she contemplated the nature of uranium.

results.abstract: Q & A column describes why photographs taken in space do not always show stars and other objects; drawing (M)
results.snippet: Q. Why don't the pictures taken from orbiting spacecraft, on the Moon, etc., show any stars in the background?    A. Some such pictures do show stars, and NASA offers a Web link to one that does: eol.jsc.nasa.gov/Images/STS039-342-25.jpg.     For...
results.lead_paragraph: Q. Why don't the pictures taken from orbiting spacecraft, on the Moon, etc., show any stars in the background? A. Some such pictures do show stars, and NASA offers a Web link to one that does: eol.jsc.nasa.gov/Images/STS039-342-25.jpg. For the most part, however, pictures taken by astronauts are in the nature of snapshots, intended to capture some well-lighted object in the foreground, like Earth or another astronaut.

results.abstract: Val Guest, filmmaker best known for his science fiction films, dies at age 94 (M)

headline.main: Val Guest, 94, Filmmaker Best Known for Science Fiction

results.snippet: Val Guest was a prolific British filmmaker known for writing and directing a spate of genre films, some of them remarkably good and some of them remarkably bad.
results.lead_paragraph: Val Guest, a prolific British filmmaker known for writing and directing a spate of genre films, some of them remarkably good and some of them remarkably bad, died on May 10 in Palm Desert, Calif. He was 94.The cause was prostate cancer, Mr. Guest's wife, Yolande Donlan, told The Los Angeles Times this week. The couple had lived in Palm Springs, Calif., in recent years. Mr. Guest was known in particular for two science fiction cult classics, ''The Day the Earth Caught Fire'' (1961) and ''The Quatermass Xperiment'' (1955), which was released in the United States as ''The Creeping Unknown.''
